-1: A knowledge graph (KG) is a graph-structured knowledge base that stores knowledge in the form of the relation between entities.
0: An example KG is DBpedia(Auer et al. 2007).
1: The KG plays an important role in various applications, e.g., question answering, browsing knowledge and data visualization.

-1: The KG plays an important role in various applications, e.g., question answering, browsing knowledge and data visualization.
0: However, most of the published data is unstructured data and the trend of publishing such data is dramatically growing faster than publishing structured data (Kriz et al. 2014).
1: Consequently, a large amount of data cannot be straightforwardly transformed into a KG and so is left as unstructured data.

-1: Consequently, a large amount of data cannot be straightforwardly transformed into a KG and so is left as unstructured data.
0: Recently, many approaches have proposed transforming unstructured text to structured text in order to create a KG (Carlson et al. 2010; Fader, Soderland, and Etzioni 2011; Schmitz et al. 2012; Cattoni et al. 2012; Augenstein, Pado, and Rudolph 2012; Kriz et al. 2014; Exner and Nugues 2012).
1: Although those studies perform well for extracting triples (subject, predicate, object) from unstructured text, they still have a limitation regarding mapping a predicate of a triple extracted from unstructured text to its identical predicate in the KG.

-1: Although those studies perform well for extracting triples (subject, predicate, object) from unstructured text, they still have a limitation regarding mapping a predicate of a triple extracted from unstructured text to its identical predicate in the KG.
0: Generally, many studies (Augenstein, Pado, and Rudolph 2012; Ratinov et al. 2011; Mendes et al. 2011) focus on mapping only an entity, which is usually a subject or an object of a triple, to its identical entity in a KG.
1: Mapping a whole predicate to its identical predicate is usually ignored.

-1: Mapping a predicate to its identical predicate in a KG is an essential procedure because it can reduce the heterogeneity problem and increase the searchability over a KG.
0: Although one study (Exner and Nugues 2012) introduced mapping a predicate of a triple extracted from unstructured text to an identical predicate in a KG, the approach uses the simple rule-based approach.
1: As a result, it cannot efficiently deal with the limitation of rule generation due to the sparsity of unstructured text.

-1: Based on these tasks, previous approaches can be roughly divided into three groups.
0: The first group (Carlson et al. 2010; Fader, Soderland, and Etzioni 2011; Schmitz et al. 2012) mainly focuses on knowledge extraction from unstructured text.
NELL (Carlson et al. 2010) is a never-ending system that learns to read the web.
1: To extract triples in NELL, bootstrap constraints are used to learn new constraints.

-1: To extract triples in NELL, bootstrap constraints are used to learn new constraints.
0: ReVerb (Fader, Soderland, and Etzioni 2011) and OLLIE (Schmitz et al. 2012) are open information systems that extract a triple from a sentence by using syntactic and lexical patterns.
1: Although these approaches successfully extract triples from unstructured text, they still do not consider entity mapping.

-1: As a result, ambiguity of an extracted entity might occur.
0: The second group (Cattoni et al. 2012; Augenstein, Pado, and Rudolph 2012; Kriz et al. 2014) also investigates knowledge extraction and entity mapping.
In some studies (Cattoni et al. 2012; Kriz et al. 2014), a triple is extracted from unstructured text by using Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques.
1: Then, a triple is stored as an RDF triple by using its own ontology.

-1: Then, a triple is stored as an RDF triple by using its own ontology.
0: LODifier (Augenstein, Pado, and Rudolph 2012) uses a deep semantic analysis system and a named entity recognition system with a coreference resolution system to acquire a triple and generates an RDF triple by using WordNet representation without considering other ontologies.
1: Even though these approaches can resolve the ambiguity of an extracted entity, all elements of a triple are not yet integrated into other KGs.

-1: Even though these approaches can resolve the ambiguity of an extracted entity, all elements of a triple are not yet integrated into other KGs.
0: The third group (Exner and Nugues 2012) considers all aspects for creating a KG.

Exner et al. use a semantic role labeling method with a state-of-the-art NLP to extract a triple from Wikipedia and then applies a rule-based approach to integrate an RDF triple into the ontology of the KG (Exner and Nugues 2012).
Although this approach (Exner and Nugues 2012) can integrate a predicate into the ontology of a KG, it still has the following severe limitation.
1: Due to the sparsity of unstructured text, bootstrapping training data for generating rules might not cover all possible patterns; consequently, some rules are missing.
